text: home and end keys in the repl take you to the bottom/top of the code block rather than the beginning/end of the line. Is there a way to change this behavior?

elements.text: home and end keys in the repl take you to the bottom/top of the code block rather than the beginning/end of the line. Is there a way to change this behavior?

text: `C-a` for beginning of line, `C-e` for end of line, of course :emacs:

elements.text: C-a
for beginning of line,
C-e
for end of line, of course

text: and press twice for beginning/end of block

elements.text: and press twice for beginning/end of block

text: that's actually just normal shell behavior, which I guess has same origin as Emacs from a historic POV

elements.text: that's actually just normal shell behavior, which I guess has same origin as Emacs from a historic POV
readline uses emacs keybindings, yes:

text: It's not the behavior of either vim or nano. Both of those have home and end moving within a line

elements.text: It's not the behavior of either vim or nano. Both of those have home and end moving within a line

text: vim is modal, so we don't use Ctrl. The home and end does whatever I guess, there's no a strong tradition I think

elements.text: vim is modal, so we don't use Ctrl. The home and end does whatever I guess, there's no a strong tradition I think

text:
> It's not the behavior of either vim or nano.
as far as I know, at least 50% of Julia creators are Emacs users, as is the main contributor to the REPL keybindings, and using readline -> Emacs keybinding is the most sensible choice :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: It's not the behavior of either vim or nano.

text: I didn't feel any Emacs-ness since most of the choice coincides with shell, clearly REPL is more like a shell (which is also a REPL) than an modal editor (vim)

elements.text: I didn't feel any Emacs-ness since most of the choice coincides with shell, clearly REPL is more like a shell (which is also a REPL) than an modal editor (vim)
